Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2011 10:03PM Mazy1959 wrote: Rosa, I wish you didnt have to go thru this at all. I'm assuming you are young. I wanted my second and third child as much as I wanted my first. Cancer changed my life too. I also had to give up my career and am limited physically. I get tired and worn out far too fast, cant run, jump or go for long walks. At first, I was saddened but accepting. I didnt cry all the time or anything but it was a huge life change. BUT.....Aside of all that, I have always been grateful to be alive and able to walk and be with my grandkids. I do pretty good for someone with stage 4 bone mets. The nerve damage gives me the most probs. I guess what I'm saying is that you need to look for what you still have. My silver lining is that I'm alive and can walk. For a few months we werent sure that my vertebrae would hold up and one wrong fall could've paralyzed me. Because of the tumor location, if treatment didnt start working as expected..it woulda spread to my organs within 6 months according to my oncs.I'm alive and living as much as I possibly can with my limitations. I've replaced many physical activities with crochet, reading and sewing etc. So maybe sit back, think of all you have and all you can do. Dont ponder too long on the what ifs...just enjoy each day to the fullest. Like Frapp said...get in and roll in it awhile. But then do your best to push it aside and do your living. Luv and Hugs, Mazy

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 10:24PM Mazy1959 wrote: Bo, I have taken oxycontin for nearly 4 years and had the same problems. I already had constipation problems to begin with. I took 14 Dulcolax, 3 extra strength Exlax and 2-4 tabblespoons of Mineral oil everyday and only went about once a week. It hurt, I was in chronic pain from it and I also bled. Onc sent me to gastro doc who started me on different meds etc...none worked better than what I was already on. I finally had to resort to mineral oil enemas in addition to the above. I started taking Omega XL ( advertised on tv) and in 2 days I was "going". I take 2 gel caps a day. My bowels have been more normal now than they ever were. I go at least 3 times a week and the bowel is normal...not hard etc. I have been so grateful for Omega XL. The drugs the gastro doc wanted me to take were $400 a month..Pmega XL is like $50 so its easier on my purse and its good for me otherwise too. I did try regular omega 3 bb4 but it didnt work. I dont have cramps, no diareah...just normal. They have a website if u r interested just search for Omeag XL. Hugs, Mazy

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 12:14AM Mazy1959 wrote: Spam..How extensive are your liver mets? Where are your bone mets? What is your treatment plan? You are Er pos and Her2 pos....have you taken any treatement for it? I was diagnosed with my first bone met in 2006 and Aromasin and Zometa took care of that for 5 yrs. Aromasin stopped working and now just a few months ago I was diagnosed with extenisve bone marrow mets throughout my lumbar spine, sacrum, hips, pelvis and right femur. So now Im on Faslodex that seems to be working. My deep pain is nearly gone. My Mo and RO were quite up front with me on the life expectancy thing. I only asked if I should get "things" in order. They told me I might live 2 months or 20 yrs. They didnt really know how long these drugs were going to work for me etc  It all depended on how i respond to treatment and if whether or not we can keep it in the bones and out of vital organs. They did agree that all the stats said I had 2-3 yrs.  That was 5 yrs and 7 months ago. So I have defied the odds but I now have alot more cancer to get rid of. Getting 5 yrs out of Aromasin is very good and I hope Faslodex is just as effective.  I do know that there are many ladies who get liver mets under control. Im thinking you should get a second opinion. I certainly would if my onc said I had 6-12 months.  Hopefully someone will post some good advice for you who is familiar with liver mets. Hugs, Mazy

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 08:54PM Mazy1959 wrote: Otter, I have been following this...thank you for input. I do not think Fairyfloss is a troll either. I do not agree with her belief that diet can cure us because I know too many people who are life long vegetarians etc and still got cancer. And I agree we each are entitled to believe what we choose and use whatever treatment we want for whatever the reason. If Fairyfloss's intentions were to truly educate ... then I do feel that we are obligated to reciprocate and offer our knowledge to her as well. So in the spirit of sharing info I am offering my knowledge.... Fairy, I appreciate your concern for your fellow man. I too share a general caring and concern for my sisters here on this board and on this site. For those who had success with the diet cure, I am happy for you. I do not knock eating healthy, etc. And certainly eating healthier is good for anyone. But I hope that some newly diagnosed person who sees your post, doesnt decide to forego medical treatment, surgery etc and assume that your information is for everyone. There are thousands of so called "cancer cures" out there and the "diet" to which you are referring has long been a topic of discussion. It is nothing new. As for our treatments causing our cancer....maybe in some cases it doesnt work as planned. For myself, without the many drugs I consume...I would have been long dead by now without them. No diet in the world could have stopped the monster I had in my back from spreading to my vital organs. Doctors guessed at perhaps a few months before it would have taken me over. Because of this.........I DO NOT want some other new person who has recently been diagnosed stage 4, to think your medical breakthrough is all she may need. So if anyone reading this is new and is considering Fairy's treatment....please educate yourself and make an informed decison. Now I will go away too...Mazy

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2012 02:46AM Mazy1959 wrote: Hi Ladies, I luv this thread. I had something happen while in the hospital and thought I'd share it with you. I went to the hospital with a sudden fever of 102.5. I was taking Abraxane at the time. Long story short, I was admitted to ICU after my vital signs and blood counts plummeted. I had sepsis, pneumonia, immunity was .02 and was spose to be 2.0, BP was 40/30 etc. One of my oncs came in the room to ask me if I wanted CPR if my heart stopped etc. I said as long as it was a temporary measure til my body could sustain itself. The onc actually tried to convince me to be DNR ( do not resuscitate). I had forgot my papers at home. My hubby was with me and he also told her I was to be resuscitated. That onc had already decided that I was not going to live thru it. After that, one nurse after another would ask me the same questions and act like I was a freak for not agreeing to be DNR. Well 5 days later I was transferred to the cancer floor from ICU. I wasnt in good shape but  had survived. The nurses on the cancer floor did the same thing. I finally had to get a little nasty with a head nurse to get it to stop. I told her that it was clear what my wishes are and that to tell the nurses, and docs to lay off. After 6 days I went home. It really bugs me that they were so convinced I was going to die and didnt want to bring me back if my heart stopped from low BP etc. I also thought I was going to die for awhile and I was scared. But they made me feel like I didnt have a chance...when I did. I may not be in the best shape but I'm still alive and am happy that I am. HUgs , Mazy

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 03:27AM Mazy1959 wrote: Hey Crazydaughter, I was diagnosed with mets to my spine , 5th lumbar in dec 2006. I was in a wheelchair for a few months and then to a cane and finally was able to get around on my own. My treatment is Zometa and Aromasin. The mets were no longer visible after 9 months. This summer we found that there was a small amount of activity back in same spot. I had kyphoplasty surgery ( bone cement injected into voids of vertbrae) and am feeling much better. I  take Oxycontin, Oxycodone, Flexeril and Lyrica for pain. If my pain gets ahead of me, it effects the whole spine, hips, legs and feet and can then start working upwards.  It is a super strong pain and the only relief for me is to stay ahead of the pain with meds. Your mom should not be suffering with pain. Once she gets the pain under control with meds her life will greatly improve. It took about 3 months before we found what worked best for me but once we did, my quality of life greatly improved. I would call the onc ASAP and stress that she is suffering and needs something for her pain. God Bless...Mazy

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2010 12:26AM Mazy1959 wrote: Undecided, I totally understand what you are going thru. I also had the most severe pain I had ever known and often said it was worse than child birth. The onc tried morpine first but it came back up. Then we tried Fentynal patch of which I had a severe reaction. Finally we settled on Oxycontin 30 mg every 8 hrs and oxcycodone for break thru. I had 9 rads that helped but not much. I dont take alot of Oxycodone for break thru since my tumor has shrunk and no longer visible. I take Oxycontin tho every 8 hrs or the pain starts to take over. The key to controIling pain is to stay ahead of it as best you can. I have found that Ibuprofen helps me more for break thru and doesnt constipate me so bad. Pain meds cause severe constipation and the more you take the worse it gets so make sure you use some stool softeners. We recently tried morphine again but it didnt work..had a reaction. My onc says she has alot of success with Oxycontin for her patients. Please feel free to PM me anytime. Hugs, Mazy

Posts.Content: May 1, 2012 03:31AM Mazy1959 wrote: keepgoin..Even if they didnt eliminate your position...you are being laid off. If it is of no fault of your own that you are losing this job then you qualify for unemployment as long you worked long enough etc. . You simply apply for unemployment and when they reject your claim they will have a hearing etc. I'm not sure about the laws etc in your area but here...you cant really fight for unemployment benefits unless you have applied and been refused. I was taking Zometa and Aromasin as my treatment when I was approved for SSDI. Being stage 4 is high priority with SSDI. I hear so many different stories from people about how they qualified. The rep at our SSD office told me straight up that if my onc wrote down that I could work as little as 2 hrs a week..I would be refused benefits. Others say they were actually still working and were approved. So I really dont understand why they dont treat each person the same on that. It didnt matter in my case because I definitley could not work even a little bit. I had stopped working the day I was dx. After 2 months we realized I would not be able to work at all and I applied online and then they set up a phone interview. I didnt even have to go to the office. The rep told me that my scans, labs etc were sufficient as proof and I didnt have to see one of their docs for further proof. I had to be off work 5 months and then started receiving my checks on the 6th month. I drew short term dis from my job until my SSDI checks started. Good luck to you and Im so sorry you even have to deal with any of this. HUgs, Mazy
Posts.Title: disability Lauriesh JillThut

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 01:53AM - edited May 18, 2012 01:57AM by Mazy1959 Cool...I am wondering if your situation may be different since you are union. I was on FMLA , still employed but on short term disabilty STD provided by employer. I was still paying for my health ins and life ins out of my STD check. I applied for SSDI and they told me that STD had no bearing on my receiving SSDI but that my employers STD would no longer be paid once I was drawing SSDI. So you would not get them both..only one. I paid COBRA for my health ins for over 2 yrs and was offered to take over the life ins but declined since it was a smaller amount anyways. Find your life ins policy..it will have in there if you can pick it up after you are no longer employed. Life ins policies are so varied theres no way to know unless you look or have HR show you. If you are questioning the HR persons knowledge..maybe ask to speak to someone else and explain that you dont think she understands and you want to make sure you are doing things right. Also try going to social security site ( google) I dont have the exact addy but go look there and it should have some answers for you and explianed better than I have . You do have to have a last day worked date as far as I know. I doubt you would get much attention from SSDI if you were still working. Good luck, Mazy

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 01:29AM Mazy1959 wrote: Bugs, I have been following this thread for awhile. The title drew me in. I saw where you mentioned that a stage 4 lady might chime in,  so here I am. I am guilty of many of the things that have been mentioned on this rant. In general I am not a politically correct type of person. I type what I feel. As for the "death watch" ..I dont think of it as such. It is much like sitting with a friend who is dying except I cant sit with all the ladies from BCO so I join in on the "being there" as best I can. Many family members print those prayers and soothing words and save them for other family members to read so yes they serve a purpose. For those of us who participate in the "being there" it is comforting to us to share our feelings because we are hurting too. I dont condemn anyone for not participating just because I do. It is a personal choice. Yes I pray for a miracle first and then for peace and comfort. Miracles do happen, why not here? Kbug and Watson were my friends. They both have participated in our vigils for others so I am pretty sure they were not offended when we did it for them.  Kbug said she could feel the prayers and love from our posts. Their families had nothing but gratitude to all of us for the prayers and kindness. We loved them like family and they knew it. I dont know where the term "Death watch" originated on this forum but that is certainly a poor description of what it actually is.  I call it "Being there".  I hope that maybe this clears up some of the ill feelings some have when one of us is dying. What seems "ick" to some is "loving" to others. We are all different but it makes none of us bad or mean spirited. Its just how it is when you have thousands of women in one breast cancer site. It would be pretty boring if we all thought the same. I agree that you shouldnt give advice unless you are sure of what you are saying. I know I have been guilty of that but hope I learned from it. Okay that was my 2 cents. I wish you all well. Hugs, Mazy

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2012 04:42PM Mazy1959 wrote: Boobuddy...you have a lump on your sternum and u are stage 3....you have bone pain. In my opinion those are all reasons to be very concerned and I would be seeing my onc and she would be getting me some scans right away. You need to have that cough checked out too. I never mean to scare people but it is what it is and you need attention. When I was first dx with bone mets in 2006 my only symptom was severe feet pain for 2 weeks. I woke up one day with severe lower back pain and by late that night I lost use of my legs (legs gave out when I went to stand). My hubby took me to ER and the met showed on a regular xray. I was dx with bone mets in my 5th lumbar vertabrae. I had great results with Aromasin and Zometa and my cancer was inactive until recently. I had been having increase pain since december but the onc I had at the time brushed it off. I asked for some scans a few months ago and the onc said i was all clear. I was NOT clear. Knowing my pain was caused by something I found my old onc who actually read the scan results which said I had extensive bone marrow mets in my hips, pelvis, lumbar spine, sacrum and right thigh. Aromasin gave me 5 yrs but was no longer working. I am now on Faslodex and hoping it works as well or better than Aromasin did. I no longer take Zometa as I have osteo necrosis of the jaw. Call your oncologist and if you arent satisfied with what he does....find a new onc. HUgs, Mazy

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2012 02:48PM Mazy1959 wrote: Psalm, I had been more tired than usual for quite some time...maybe 6 months or so. I was in alot of pain and it was wearing me out emotionally as well as physically. The onc who didnt give a damn told me that I was getting older, probly did too much, I was fine cause my labs were ok, maybe I needed to have physical therapy, and on and on and on. He was an idiot !!!!! I needed attention, I needed treatment and no matter what I said..he brushed me off. You are your own best advocate and always listen to what your body is trying to tell you. I pray for great results on the 25th. Layla,  I was diagnosed stage 2B ILC and then my first bone met was diagnosed 3yr and 9 mo later. I have new mets now and it had been 5 yr and 5 mo since the last one til this was found. Do you know what percentage ER positive you were? I am and have always been 90% ER pos. To anyone who is fearful that cancer may be sneaking back in...I know you have probly heard this a hundred times. But honestly...If your symptoms have lasted 2 weeks or more or if they are severe...then you need checked out by your onc. Sometimes symptoms gradually worsen and you dont pay attention at first. When you start thinking that you should be checked then you probly do. If you are not satisfied with what your onc does or says...tell him so and ask til you are satisfied. If you dont feel your onc is right...get another opinion. Its your life they have in their hands and you need to do what you can to make sure they pay attention. HUgs, Mazy

My first onc told me there is a high concentration of many cancers along both sides of the river. Is it that?? we really dont know but I do think its a good guess. Theres not just one thing that stands out to make the river guilty but maybe a combination of things. I think there are different causes for most of us. Different causes maybe depending on what type of breast cancer we have. Over the years they have announced many things that caused cancer only to back track later on and find they were wrong. It's a crap shoot for now. Hugs

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 03:12AM - edited Oct 24, 2007 03:15AM by Mazy1959 Hi noon,  So sorry you have had to join us. I have bone mets in my spine on the 5th lumbar. I took 14 treatments of radiation and take Aromasin and also Zometa infusions once monthly. The Zometa healed my bone totally. I have feeling back in my leg and feet. My tumor is stable. I have no probs with Zometa. I am on SSDI now and am considered permanently disabled but I really do pretty good as long as I'm careful. Getting my pain under control was the biggest challenge we had. After trying different combos of drugs we finally found that Oxycontin 20mg every 12 hours and Oxycodone/Tyl 5/325 for break away pain was best for me. I get very sick on morphine and some of the others and couldnt tolerate them. I sleep with a heating pad and take hot soaks in the tub to loosen me up in the mornings. My worst time of day is when I'm first trying to get up..I'm soooo stiff.  Hope it all works out for you. Mazy

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 10:36PM Mazy1959 wrote: Mason, I have severe constipation caused from my pain meds also. I take 2 Dulcolax softeners with each pain pill, calcium pill and any other drug known to cause constipation for a total of 14 a day (LOL I know its crazy). I also take 3 extra strength ExLax and use 6 tablespoons of mineral oil (i take these thru out day). Recently I went to a gastro doc and he added Lactulose. I have only been on it 8 days. I had one good BM so far. I was only going a small amount every 6-7 days so hopefully this will help. Doc said it may take a while for it to show alot of benefits. I have found that using glycerine suppositories with lots of vaseline on it do help things to be less painful when they come out. Miralax, Metamucil, Benfiber, Phillips mag etc do not help me at all. If youcant get it under control get into a good gastroentologist and he will take care of you. HUgs, Mazy

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 06:22PM - edited Mar 2, 2009 06:24PM by Mazy1959 tara, What about a PET scan or maybe a ct? I would keep looking for a doctor who will listen to you. Having had LCIS should be reason enough. My question is this...if your oncs and gyno can feel them then why cant they ask for another biopsy? My biopsy was not done by a breast surgeon, it was done by a chief radiologist. There are other surgeons who can also do them. I know it may seem better to have a breast surgeon  but I am saying that it doesnt have to be. Do you know how many samples they took during your biospy? On one of mine...it came back inconclusive and that was the reason they repeated it. By the way, I was skinny as a bean pole when I was diagnosed..so thin that it was mentioned in my reports, and that was never even mentioned as a reason to ignore anything. I am no doctor but I strongly advise you to get a second or third opinion. The top quadrant, nearest your armpit is, according to my oncs and surgeon, an area of concern. Lobular breast cancer is sneaky and it like s to hide. Until if or when you get something more conclusive, keep a very close eye on things. I have lobular and the lump in my breast was rock hard, painful and it moved easily. It just kinda popped up and made itself known when I saw it in the mirror one night. I was seen by a surgeon within 2 days and was in the operating room within the week and my surgeon said that it had grown during that time. I know that is unusual but my surgeon said that some lobular tumors are known for that. I am not trying to scare you...but I agree with you that you have a valid concern and I would be asking my oncs or gyno to arrange for another biopsy soon. Keep in touch, Hugs, Mazy
